title: Libor-style scandals could happen again as banks are failing to reform, says FCA
text:
Print 
No bank or brokerage has taken enough action to enforce good behaviour, the Financial Conduct Authority says 
Market-fixing scandals could happen again because banks and brokerages have not taken enough steps to monitor their staff, according to the Financial Conduct Authority, three years on from the Libor interest rate fixing scandal. 
Despite more than £2bn in UK fines for Libor and foreign exchange benchmark manipulation , as well as action from the EU and US, banks are still showing a worrying lack of urgency in reforming their internal controls and systems to make sure there is no repeat of the scandals, the financial watchdog said on Wednesday in a strongly worded report. 
The City was shocked when banks were fined for forex manipulation, as it was revealed that the bad behaviour carried on even after the Libor scandal had broken . 
But even now, banks have failed to act to stop another repeat. 
“The progress to improve oversight and controls around benchmark activities across most firms and within individual firms appeared slow,” said the FCA. 
“This lack of urgency is disappointing given the importance of benchmarks to the economy, the similarity and severity of a number of previous benchmark failures, the high level of public concern as a result of the misconduct made public, and the scale of enforcement fines levied on firms.” 
Banks still need to manage or remove conflicts of interest, the FCA said, which can arise when a trader’s profit or loss is affected by the level of a benchmark that they can personally influence. 
Tracey McDermott, who will soon be the FCA's interim chief executive, said banks have taken some action to improve behaviour, but need to do far more 
Firms also need to properly manage those staff involved in setting benchmarks, monitoring their work and identifying exactly which member of staff is responsible for each part of work related to the benchmarks. 
Brokerages and banks also need to make sure they know exactly how many benchmarks they are involved in setting, and where they are these include internally compiled benchmarks, which may not be used by the wider markets, but still impact their customers. 
The FCA’s director of supervision Tracey McDermott who will become the regulator’s interim chief executive in September said these changes would be crucial to restoring trust in the financial sector. 
“We have seen widespread historic misconduct in relation to benchmarks. It is now critical that firms act to restore trust and confidence in the system,” she said. 
“Firms should have in place systems to manage the risks posed by benchmark activities and to address the weaknesses that have previously been identified.” 
More changes are on their way from regulators. 
The Bank of England is working with authorities around the world to draw up a global code of conduct for currency traders . 
On April 1, regulators added seven more benchmarks including gold, silver and oil indices to the list of those covered by tighter rules, which include the threat of prosecution and jail terms for traders who try to manipulate the markets.
